<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 194, 220, 209]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 215, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 826, 92]]<|/det|>
The coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \(\left(k + \frac{1}{3} x\right)^{5}\) is 30. Find the value of the constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 117, 92, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 116, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The first and second terms of a progression are 4 and 8 respectively. Find the sum of the first 10 terms given that the progression is

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 157, 153, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 156, 369, 175]]<|/det|>
an arithmetic progression,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 157, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 180, 153, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 358, 199]]<|/det|>
a geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 223, 92, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 230, 756, 465]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 887, 504]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = 2x^{5} + 3x^{3}\) and the line \(y = 2x\) intersecting at points \(A\), \(O\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 514, 153, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 514, 776, 532]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\) satisfy the equation \(2x^{4} + 3x^{2} - 2 = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 543, 153, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 543, 920, 577]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(2x^{4} + 3x^{2} - 2 = 0\) and hence find the coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\), giving your answers in an exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 603, 94, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 612, 722, 794]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 808, 920, 842]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(ABCD\) is a parallelogram with \(AB = BD = DC = 10 \text{ cm}\) and angle \(ABD = 0.8\) radians. \(APD\) and \(BQC\) are arcs of circles with centres \(B\) and \(D\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 853, 153, 871]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 853, 494, 871]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the parallelogram \(ABCD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 853, 920, 871]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 881, 151, 900]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 881, 539, 900]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the complete figure \(ABQCDP\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 910, 151, 928]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 910, 581, 928]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the complete figure \(ABQCDP\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 910, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 245, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 245, 91]]<|/det|>
Given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 92, 598, 112]]<|/det|>
\[3\sin^{2}x - 8\cos x - 7 = 0,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 117, 401, 135]]<|/det|>
show that, for real values of \(x\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 135, 544, 157]]<|/det|>
\[\cos x = -\frac{2}{3}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 173, 153, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 173, 361, 191]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 197, 655, 217]]<|/det|>
\[3\sin^{2}(\theta +70^{\circ}) - 8\cos (\theta +70^{\circ}) - 7 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 301, 244]]<|/det|>
for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 272, 96, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
Relative to an origin \(O\), the position vectors of points \(A\) and \(B\) are \(3\mathbf{i} + 4\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}\) and \(5\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j} - 3\mathbf{k}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 317, 151, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 317, 475, 336]]<|/det|>
Use a scalar product to find angle \(BOA\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 707, 371]]<|/det|>
The point \(C\) is the mid-point of \(AB\). The point \(D\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{OD} = 2\overrightarrow{OB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 386, 151, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 384, 237, 405]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{DC}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 388, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 434, 96, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 434, 920, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label> A straight line passes through the point (2, 0) and has gradient \(m\). Write down the equation of the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 451, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 481, 151, 499]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 481, 920, 514]]<|/det|>
Find the two values of \(m\) for which the line is a tangent to the curve \(y = x^{2} - 4x + 5\). For each value of \(m\), find the coordinates of the point where the line touches the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 498, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 151, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
Express \(x^{2} - 4x + 5\) in the form \((x + a)^{2} + b\) and hence, or otherwise, write down the coordinates of the minimum point on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 590, 96, 608]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 920, 623]]<|/det|>
A curve \(y = \operatorname {f}(x)\) has a stationary point at \(P\left(3, - 10\right)\). It is given that \(\operatorname {f}'(x) = 2x^{2} + kx - 12\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 636, 156, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 636, 809, 655]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = -2\) and hence find the \(x\)-coordinate of the other stationary point, \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 637, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 666, 153, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 666, 771, 685]]<|/det|>
Find \(\operatorname {f}''(x)\) and determine the nature of each of the stationary points \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[868, 667, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 698, 240, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 698, 240, 715]]<|/det|>
Find \(\operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 698, 920, 715]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 744, 96, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 744, 376, 761]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 768, 608, 787]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}:x\mapsto 2x + 3\qquad \mathrm{for} x\leqslant 0,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 789, 608, 808]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}:x\mapsto x^{2} - 6x\quad \mathrm{for} x\leqslant 3.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 831, 151, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 829, 675, 848]]<|/det|>
Express \(\operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\) in terms of \(x\) and solve the equation \(\operatorname {f}(x) = \operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 831, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 861, 151, 880]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 861, 920, 895]]<|/det|>
On the same diagram sketch the graphs of \(y = \operatorname {f}(x)\) and \(y = \operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\), showing the coordinates of their point of intersection and the relationship between the graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 883, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 910, 148, 927]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 908, 569, 927]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(x\) which satisfy \(\operatorname {gf}(x) \leqslant 16\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 82, 745, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 365, 873, 386]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the line \(y = x + 1\) and the curve \(y = \sqrt{(x + 1)}\) , meeting at \((- 1, 0)\) and \((0, 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 397, 153, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 396, 437, 415]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 397, 918, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 428, 153, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 428, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
Find the volume obtained when the shaded region is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(\mathbf{y}\) -axis. [7]
